greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways to write 2n = p+q with p and q both prime, p+1 and q-1 both practical.
comment: As p+q=(p+1)+(q-1), this unifies Goldbach's conjecture and its analog involving practical numbers.
The conjecture has been verified for n up to 10^7.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
G. Melfi, On two conjectures about practical numbers, J. Number Theory 56 (1996) 205-210 [MR96i:11106].
Zhi-Wei Sun, Conjectures involving primes and quadratic forms, arXiv:1211.1588 [math.NT], 2012-2017.
example: a(8) = 2 since 2*8 = 3+13 = 11+5 with 3, 5, 11, 13 all prime and 3+1, 13-1, 11+1, 5-1 all practical.
mathematica: Con[n_]:=Con[n]=Sum[If[Part[Part[f[n], s+1], 1]<=DivisorSigma[1, Product[Pow[n, i], {i, 1, s}]]+1, 0, 1], {s, 1, Length[f[n]]-1}]
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Jan 19 2013
